stages.description: Tiny achene barely visible to the naked eye. Needs light and cool stratification to break dormancy — press onto the surface, never bury.
A hair-thin radicle emerges after a long wait. Alpine strawberries test your patience from the very first day.
Two tiny round cotyledons open. The first true leaf unfolds as a miniature trifoliate — three serrated leaflets on a thread-like petiole.
The crown fills with trifoliate leaves on lengthening petioles. Runners begin creeping outward, rooting at nodes to establish daughter plants.
Small white five-petaled flowers with bright yellow centers rise just above the foliage. Everbearing — new flowers keep appearing alongside developing fruit.
Tiny conical berries ripen from pale green to brilliant red. Intensely sweet and aromatic — more flavor per gram than any garden strawberry. Birds will find them before you do.
Foliage reddens and dies back as frost arrives, but the crown persists underground. Runners have already established next year's colony.

companions.lore: Lettuce and strawberries are classic interplanting partners — shallow-rooted lettuce fills gaps between strawberry rows without competing, and both prefer cool, moist soil.
Deep-rooted carrots and shallow-rooted strawberries occupy different soil layers entirely. The carrot taproot loosens subsoil, improving drainage around strawberry crowns.
Basil's aromatic oils deter aphids and spider mites that target strawberry foliage. The strong scent also confuses spotted wing drosophila seeking ripe fruit.

antagonists.lore: Fennel's allelopathic root exudates inhibit strawberry crown development. A poor neighbor for most Rosaceae.
Brassicas are heavy feeders that deplete the same nutrients strawberries need for crown establishment and fruit set.

stages.description: A fuzzy gray-brown mold appears on ripe and overripe fruit, especially where berries touch the soil. Botrytis cinerea — the signature strawberry rot.
Mold spreads to flower petals and leaves in wet conditions. Affected fruit collapses into a gray spore mass. Remove infected material immediately.
Crown tissue softens as the fungus invades the plant's core. Entire trusses of fruit rot on the stem. The plant may survive but yield is devastated.
Outer leaves develop dry brown margins that curl inward. Inner leaves may look fine at first — the soil-borne fungus is blocking water transport from the roots up.
One side of the plant wilts and flattens while the other remains turgid. Cut a runner and the vascular tissue shows brown streaking.
Entire plant collapses. Crown cross-section reveals a ring of darkened vascular tissue. Soil remains infected for years — do not replant strawberries here.
Small dark purple spots appear on upper leaf surfaces. Diplocarpon earlianum — a fungus that thrives in warm, humid weather.
Spots merge into large irregular burned-looking patches. Leaf margins dry and curl upward. Heavily affected leaves detach at the petiole.

lore.description: A dainty perennial ground cover that produces tiny, intensely flavored berries all season long. What alpine strawberries lack in size they repay tenfold in fragrance and sweetness.
lore.origin: Mountainous regions across Europe and northern Asia; cultivated since the 14th century, long before the modern garden strawberry was hybridized
lore.fun_fact: The modern garden strawberry (Fragaria × ananassa) was created in the 1750s by crossing a Chilean species with a Virginian one — but alpine strawberry lovers insist the original wild flavor was lost in the pursuit of size.
